action_space.name: Therapeutic Alliance and Agenda Setting
action_space.description: Establishes rapport, clarifies roles, and collaboratively defines the session focus and expectations.

goal.objective: Create a safe, collaborative foundation and a clear agenda for the CBT session.

success_levels.ideal: Patient feels understood, engaged, and agrees on a clear, shared agenda.
success_levels.acceptable: Basic rapport is established and a tentative agenda is set.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient feels misunderstood, disengaged, or the session lacks direction.

goal.reward_hint: Patient expresses comfort, willingness to engage, and agreement on session goals.

states: Patient expresses uncertainty about therapy process

micro_actions.name: Warm Greeting and Normalization
micro_actions.description: Therapist offers a welcoming greeting and normalizes the therapy experience.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Agenda Proposal
micro_actions.description: Therapist suggests possible topics and invites the patient to prioritize them.
states: Unstructured or drifting conversation early in session

action_space.name: Problem Exploration and Emotional Validation
action_space.description: Elicits detailed descriptions of the patient’s difficulties while validating emotional experiences.

goal.objective: Develop a shared understanding of the patient’s problems and emotional context.

success_levels.ideal: Patient openly shares experiences and feels emotionally validated.
success_levels.acceptable: Key problems are identified with moderate emotional engagement.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient remains vague, defensive, or emotionally disconnected.

goal.reward_hint: Patient provides concrete examples and acknowledges feeling understood.

states: Problems are vague or poorly specified

micro_actions.name: Open-Ended Inquiry
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks open questions to encourage detailed sharing.
states: Patient gives brief or surface-level responses
Need to expand on a reported issue

micro_actions.name: Empathic Reflection
micro_actions.description: Therapist reflects feelings and meanings to validate the patient’s experience.

action_space.name: Cognitive Assessment and Case Formulation
action_space.description: Identifies automatic thoughts, beliefs, and cognitive patterns linked to emotions and behaviors.

goal.objective: Build a shared CBT formulation connecting thoughts, emotions, and behaviors.

success_levels.ideal: Patient recognizes and articulates key automatic thoughts and patterns.
success_levels.acceptable: Some cognitive links are identified with therapist support.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient cannot identify or engage with cognitive aspects.

micro_actions.name: Thought Elicitation
micro_actions.description: Therapist asks targeted questions to uncover automatic thoughts.

micro_actions.name: Summarizing Cognitive Links
micro_actions.description: Therapist summarizes how thoughts, feelings, and behaviors interact.

action_space.name: Cognitive Restructuring and Behavioral Experimentation
action_space.description: Guides the patient to evaluate and modify maladaptive thoughts and test new behaviors.

goal.objective: Reduce maladaptive thinking and promote more adaptive beliefs and behaviors.

success_levels.ideal: Patient generates balanced thoughts and commits to adaptive actions.
success_levels.acceptable: Patient questions maladaptive thoughts with therapist guidance.

goal.reward_hint: Patient expresses alternative perspectives or willingness to try new behaviors.

micro_actions.name: Socratic Questioning
micro_actions.description: Therapist uses guided questions to examine evidence for and against thoughts.
states: Patient expresses certainty in negative beliefs

micro_actions.name: Behavioral Experiment Planning
micro_actions.description: Therapist collaborates to design small experiments to test beliefs.

action_space.name: Consolidation, Homework, and Session Closure
action_space.description: Reinforces learning, assigns between-session tasks, and closes the session collaboratively.

goal.objective: Ensure learning is consolidated and translated into between-session practice.

success_levels.ideal: Patient clearly summarizes insights and commits to homework.
success_levels.acceptable: Homework is assigned with basic understanding.
success_levels.unsuccessful: Patient leaves unclear or unmotivated to practice.

goal.reward_hint: Patient accurately summarizes session and agrees to specific next steps.

micro_actions.name: Session Summarization
micro_actions.description: Therapist reviews main points and invites patient feedback.

micro_actions.name: Homework Assignment
micro_actions.description: Therapist collaboratively defines concrete, achievable homework tasks.
states: Patient shows readiness to apply skills

conversation_states.Description: Tracks the intensity of the patient’s current emotional activation (e.g., distress, anxiety, sadness). High arousal may require grounding or validation before cognitive work, while low arousal allows deeper restructuring.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = no emotional activation, 1 = extreme emotional activation

conversation_states.Description: Represents the dominant emotion expressed by the patient, guiding emotion-specific interventions (e.g., anxiety vs. guilt require different techniques).
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = no clear dominant emotion, 1 = very clearly defined dominant emotion

conversation_states.Description: Indicates how strongly identifiable cognitive distortions (e.g., catastrophizing, overgeneralization) are present in the patient’s statements, guiding when to initiate cognitive restructuring.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = no detectable distortion, 1 = distortion dominates thinking

conversation_states.Description: Tracks the patient’s awareness that thoughts influence emotions and behaviors, which is critical for readiness to engage in CBT techniques.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = no awareness, 1 = full understanding and articulation

conversation_states.Description: Reflects the extent to which the patient is engaging in adaptive or avoidance-related behaviors, informing whether behavioral activation or exposure is appropriate.
Represents the patient’s motivational stage and willingness to try new perspectives or behaviors, guiding pacing and intervention intensity.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = no readiness for change, 1 = fully ready and proactive

conversation_states.Description: Captures the level of trust, collaboration, and rapport between therapist and patient, which affects receptiveness to interventions.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = no alliance, 1 = very strong collaborative bond

conversation_states.Description: Tracks whether the session is currently oriented toward emotion processing, cognitive restructuring, behavioral planning, or meta-discussion, supporting state-aware action selection.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = unfocused or drifting, 1 = highly focused on a clear goal

conversation_states.Description: Measures how actively the patient participates (e.g., elaboration, reflection, asking questions), informing whether to probe, support, or re-engage.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = fully disengaged, 1 = fully engaged and responsive

conversation_states.Description: Assesses the patient’s ability to tolerate and regulate emotions during the conversation, guiding whether regulation skills are needed before deeper work.
conversation_states.Numerical values: 0 = unable to regulate emotions, 1 = fully able to self-regulate

nodes.description: Root entity representing the individual receiving cognitive behavioral therapy across multiple sessions.
Deeply held, stable beliefs about self, others, and the world that influence emotional and behavioral patterns.
Underlying assumptions, rules, and attitudes that mediate between core beliefs and automatic thoughts.
Recurring automatic thoughts that arise in specific situations and are linked to emotional responses.
Common emotional responses and affective trends observed across situations and sessions.
Habitual behaviors, avoidance strategies, and coping actions exhibited over time.
Systematic thinking errors such as catastrophizing or overgeneralization that recur across sessions.
Internal or external situations and cues that reliably activate maladaptive thoughts or emotions.
Long-term and intermediate treatment objectives collaboratively defined during therapy.
CBT techniques and coping skills learned and practiced by the patient over multiple sessions.
Longitudinal assessment of symptom change, goal attainment, and functional improvement.
Persistent vulnerabilities and conditions that increase the likelihood of symptom recurrence.

cautions.description: Offering solutions or coping strategies before fully understanding the patient's thoughts, emotions, and context.
cautions.risk: The patient may feel misunderstood or dismissed, reducing engagement and weakening the therapeutic alliance.

cautions.description: Downplaying, minimizing, or challenging the legitimacy of the patient's emotional experience.
cautions.risk: Can increase shame, emotional withdrawal, or resistance, undermining trust and emotional safety.

cautions.description: Rigidly directing the session or imposing interpretations without collaborative discussion.
cautions.risk: Reduces patient autonomy and collaboration, which are core mechanisms of change in CBT.

cautions.description: Providing long theoretical explanations without checking relevance or patient understanding.
cautions.risk: May overwhelm the patient cognitively and shift the session away from experiential learning.

cautions.description: Introducing complex cognitive restructuring techniques when the patient is emotionally dysregulated or not ready.
cautions.risk: Techniques may fail or backfire, increasing frustration and perceived therapy ineffectiveness.

cautions.description: Confronting or disputing core beliefs in a forceful or argumentative manner.
cautions.risk: Can trigger defensiveness, rupture alliance, and entrench maladaptive beliefs.

cautions.description: Failing to assess risk factors such as suicidality or self-harm when indicators are present.
cautions.risk: May result in unaddressed safety risks with serious ethical and clinical consequences.

cautions.description: Assuming the meaning of patient experiences without explicit clarification or validation.
cautions.risk: Leads to misformulation of problems and ineffective or misaligned interventions.

cautions.description: Applying CBT techniques without a shared and coherent case formulation.
cautions.risk: Interventions may appear arbitrary, reducing coherence and treatment effectiveness.

cautions.description: Failing to consider cultural, social, or personal values shaping the patient’s beliefs and behaviors.
cautions.risk: May cause misunderstandings, reduce relevance of interventions, and harm engagement.

user_profile.Description: Typical way the patient interprets events and constructs meaning, influencing automatic thoughts and core beliefs.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = highly flexible and balanced thinking, 1 = rigid and biased thinking patterns

user_profile.Description: Baseline intensity and speed of emotional responses to internal or external triggers.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = emotionally stable with low reactivity, 1 = intense and rapidly escalating emotional responses

user_profile.Description: General tendency to engage in goal-directed, rewarding, or avoidance-related behaviors.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = severely inactive or avoidant, 1 = highly active and behaviorally engaged

user_profile.Description: Degree to which the patient understands their own thoughts, emotions, and behavioral patterns.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = little to no awareness of internal processes, 1 = strong reflective understanding of patterns

user_profile.Description: Stable readiness and willingness to engage in therapeutic work and behavior change.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = no desire for change, 1 = strong and sustained commitment to change

user_profile.Description: Typical way the patient relates to and collaborates with the therapist.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = distrustful or disengaged stance, 1 = open, collaborative partnership

user_profile.Description: How emotions are usually communicated during sessions.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = minimal emotional expression, 1 = intense and frequent emotional expression

user_profile.Description: Habitual strategies used to manage stress and negative emotions.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = predominantly maladaptive coping, 1 = predominantly adaptive coping

user_profile.Description: Ability to consider alternative perspectives and update beliefs when presented with evidence.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = very rigid beliefs, 1 = highly flexible and adaptive thinking

user_profile.Description: Sensitivity to perceived evaluation, rejection, or interpersonal feedback.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = little concern about others’ evaluations, 1 = highly sensitive to interpersonal cues

user_profile.Description: General belief in one’s ability to cope with challenges and implement change.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = strong sense of helplessness, 1 = strong belief in personal competence

user_profile.Description: Preference and tolerance for structured interventions such as homework, agendas, and worksheets.
user_profile.Numerical values: 0 = resists structure and tasks, 1 = strongly prefers clear structure and guidance
